title: Binance founder moves to dismiss $1.8B lawsuit
description: Binance founder Changpeng Zhao has filed a motion to dismiss the $1.76 billion lawsuit from the FTX estate, arguing the U.S. court has no jurisdiction and he was improperly served.
content:
Binance founder Changpeng Zhao has filed a motion to dismiss the $1.76 billion lawsuit from the FTX estate, arguing the U.S. court has no jurisdiction and he was improperly served.

Binance founder Changpeng “CZ” Zhao has filed a motion to dismiss a $1.76 billion lawsuit brought by the FTX bankruptcy estate, arguing that a U.S. court has no legal grounds to pursue the case.

Filed on August 5 in Delaware Bankruptcy Court, the motion claims that Zhao, a UAE resident, was “improperly served” and that the court has no personal jurisdiction over him. “Mr. Zhao is not amenable to suit in this forum,” the filing reads. “The claims are in any event legally unfounded, and many are outright incoherent.”

Join the discussion with CryptoWendyO on Roundtable here.

The case centers on a July 2021 equity buyback deal in which FTX repurchased Binance’s 20% stake using a mix of FTT tokens and Binance-branded assets like BUSD. FTX alleges the funds used were misappropriated customer deposits and is now seeking to recover them as part of its bankruptcy proceedings.

Zhao’s legal team argues he wasn’t the recipient of any funds. “Plaintiffs in fact show that Mr. Zhao was not a transferee,” the filing states. “They allege he was merely a nominal counterparty in the transfer of BUSD from Alameda LTD to Binance.”

This follows similar motions to dismiss filed by other Binance executives in July.

The FTX estate claims Zhao played a broader role in FTX’s collapse, referencing his 2022 tweet that sparked a wave of customer withdrawals. However, Zhao maintains he had no direct involvement and served only as a “nominal signatory.”

Zhao previously served a four-month sentence in the U.S. for violating anti-money laundering laws in a separate case, stepping down as Binance CEO as part of a $4.3 billion settlement with U.S. regulators.

The case was filed in Delaware Bankruptcy Court and centers on a July 2021 equity buyback deal where FTX repurchased Binance’s 20% stake using a mix of FTT tokens and Binance-branded assets. FTX alleges the funds used were misappropriated customer deposits and is seeking to recover them as part of its bankruptcy proceedings. Zhao maintains he was only a nominal signatory in the transfer of BUSD from Alameda LTD to Binance.
shortSummary: Binance founder Changpeng Zhao is seeking to dismiss a $1.76 billion lawsuit from FTX, alleging improper service and legal inconsistencies.
